config.text: When may you stop on an urban clearway?

choices.label: To set down and pick up passengers
To use a mobile telephone
To ask for directions
To load or unload goods

correct.text: Urban clearways have their times of operation clearly signed. You may only stop to pick up or set down passengers.

incorrect.text: Urban clearways have their times of operation clearly signed. You may only stop to pick up or set down passengers.

config.text: What should you do when there's an obstruction on your side of the road?

choices.label: Carry on, as you have priority
Give way to oncoming traffic
Wave oncoming vehicles through
Accelerate to get past first

correct.text: Take care if you have to pass an obstruction, such as a parked vehicle, on your side of the road. Give way to oncoming traffic if there isn’t enough room for you both to continue safely.

incorrect.text: Take care if you have to pass an obstruction, such as a parked vehicle, on your side of the road. Give way to oncoming traffic if there isn’t enough room for you both to continue safely.

config.text: Which vehicle might have to take a different course from normal at a roundabout?

choices.label: Sports car
Van
Estate car
Long vehicle

correct.text:
A long vehicle may have to straddle lanes either on or approaching a roundabout so that the rear wheels don’t mount the kerb.
If you’re following a long vehicle, stay well back and give it plenty of room.

incorrect.text:
A long vehicle may have to straddle lanes either on or approaching a roundabout so that the rear wheels don’t mount the kerb.
If you’re following a long vehicle, stay well back and give it plenty of room.

config.text: Where's the safest place to park your vehicle at night?

choices.label: In a garage
On a busy road
In a quiet car park
Near a red route

correct.text: If you have a garage, use it. Your vehicle is less likely to be a victim of car crime if it's in a garage. Also, in winter, the windows will be kept free from ice and snow.

incorrect.text: If you have a garage, use it. Your vehicle is less likely to be a victim of car crime if it's in a garage. Also, in winter, the windows will be kept free from ice and snow.

config.text: A single carriageway road has this sign. What's the maximum permitted speed for a car towing a trailer?

choices.label: 30 mph
40 mph
50 mph
60 mph

correct.text: When you're towing a trailer, a reduced speed limit also applies on dual carriageways and motorways. These lower speed limits apply to vehicles pulling all sorts of trailers, including caravans and horse boxes.

incorrect.text: When you're towing a trailer, a reduced speed limit also applies on dual carriageways and motorways. These lower speed limits apply to vehicles pulling all sorts of trailers, including caravans and horse boxes.

config.text: You want to turn right at a box junction. What should you do if there's oncoming traffic?

choices.label: Wait in the box junction if your exit is clear
Wait before the junction until it's clear of all traffic
Drive on; you can't turn right at a box junction
Drive slowly into the box junction when signalled by oncoming traffic

correct.text: You can wait in the box junction as long as your exit is clear. At some point there'll be a gap in the oncoming traffic, or the traffic lights will change, allowing you to proceed.

incorrect.text: You can wait in the box junction as long as your exit is clear. At some point there'll be a gap in the oncoming traffic, or the traffic lights will change, allowing you to proceed.

config.text: You're looking for somewhere to safely park your vehicle. Where would you choose to park?

choices.label: At or near a bus stop
In a designated parking space
Near the brow of a hill
On the approach to a level crossing

correct.text: It may be tempting to park where you shouldn’t while you run a quick errand. Careless parking is a selfish act and could endanger other road users.

incorrect.text: It may be tempting to park where you shouldn’t while you run a quick errand. Careless parking is a selfish act and could endanger other road users.

config.text: You're driving in the right-hand lane of a dual carriageway. What should you do if you see a sign showing that the right-hand lane is closed 800 yards ahead?

choices.label: Keep in that lane until you reach the queue
Move to the left immediately
Wait and see which lane is moving faster
Move to the left in good time

correct.text:
Keep a lookout for traffic signs. If you’re directed to change lanes, do so in good time. Don’t
  • push your way into traffic in another lane
  • try to gain advantage by delaying changing lanes.

incorrect.text:
Keep a lookout for traffic signs. If you’re directed to change lanes, do so in good time. Don’t
  • push your way into traffic in another lane
  • try to gain advantage by delaying changing lanes.

config.text: What does this sign mean?

choices.label: Minimum speed 30 mph
End of maximum speed
End of minimum speed
Maximum speed 30 mph

correct.text: The red slash through the sign indicates that the restriction has ended. In this case, the restriction was a minimum speed limit of 30 mph.

incorrect.text: The red slash through the sign indicates that the restriction has ended. In this case, the restriction was a minimum speed limit of 30 mph.

config.text: What's the meaning of this sign?

choices.label: Local speed limit applies
No waiting on the carriageway
National speed limit applies
No entry for vehicles

correct.text: This sign doesn't tell you the speed limit in figures. You should know the speed limit for the type of road that you're on and the type of vehicle that you're driving or riding. Study your copy of The Highway Code.

incorrect.text: This sign doesn't tell you the speed limit in figures. You should know the speed limit for the type of road that you're on and the type of vehicle that you're driving or riding. Study your copy of The Highway Code.

config.text: You're going to turn left from a main road into a minor road. What should you do as you approach the junction?

choices.label: Keep just left of the middle of the road
Keep in the middle of the road
Swing out to the right just before turning
Keep well to the left of the road

correct.text: Your road position can help other road users to anticipate your actions. Keep to the left as you approach a left turn and don't swing out into the centre of the road in order to make the turn easier. This could endanger oncoming traffic and may cause other road users to misunderstand your intentions.

incorrect.text: Your road position can help other road users to anticipate your actions. Keep to the left as you approach a left turn and don't swing out into the centre of the road in order to make the turn easier. This could endanger oncoming traffic and may cause other road users to misunderstand your intentions.

config.text: You're driving on a road that has a cycle lane. What does it mean if the lane is marked by a broken white line?

choices.label: You shouldn't drive in the lane unless it's unavoidable
There's a reduced speed limit for motor vehicles using the lane
Cyclists can travel in both directions in that lane
The lane must be used by motorcyclists in heavy traffic

correct.text: Cycle lanes are marked with either a solid or a broken white line. If the line is solid, you should check the times of operation shown on the signs, and not drive or park in the lane during those times. If the line is broken, you shouldn't drive or park in the lane unless it's unavoidable.

incorrect.text: Cycle lanes are marked with either a solid or a broken white line. If the line is solid, you should check the times of operation shown on the signs, and not drive or park in the lane during those times. If the line is broken, you shouldn't drive or park in the lane unless it's unavoidable.

config.text: Who is authorised to signal you to stop?

choices.label: A motorcyclist
A pedestrian
A police officer
A bus driver

correct.text: You must obey signals to stop given by police and traffic officers, traffic wardens and school crossing patrols. Failure to do so is an offence and could lead to prosecution.

incorrect.text: You must obey signals to stop given by police and traffic officers, traffic wardens and school crossing patrols. Failure to do so is an offence and could lead to prosecution.

config.text: What's the nearest you may park to a junction?

choices.label: 10 metres (32 feet)
12 metres (39 feet)
15 metres (49 feet)
20 metres (66 feet)

correct.text: Don't park within 10 metres (32 feet) of a junction (unless in an authorised parking place). This is to allow drivers emerging from, or turning into, the junction a clear view of the road they're joining. It also allows them to see hazards such as pedestrians or cyclists at the junction.

incorrect.text: Don't park within 10 metres (32 feet) of a junction (unless in an authorised parking place). This is to allow drivers emerging from, or turning into, the junction a clear view of the road they're joining. It also allows them to see hazards such as pedestrians or cyclists at the junction.

config.text: When may you enter a box junction?

choices.label: When there are fewer than two vehicles ahead
When signalled by another road user
When your exit road is clear
When traffic signs direct you

correct.text: Yellow box junctions are marked on the road to prevent the road becoming blocked. Don’t enter the box unless your exit road is clear. You may wait in the box if you want to turn right and your exit road is clear but oncoming traffic or other vehicles waiting to turn right are preventing you from making the turn.

incorrect.text: Yellow box junctions are marked on the road to prevent the road becoming blocked. Don’t enter the box unless your exit road is clear. You may wait in the box if you want to turn right and your exit road is clear but oncoming traffic or other vehicles waiting to turn right are preventing you from making the turn.

config.text: You're turning right at a crossroads. An oncoming driver is also turning right. What's the advantage of turning behind the oncoming vehicle?

choices.label: You'll have a clearer view of any approaching traffic
You'll use less fuel because you can stay in a higher gear
You'll have more time to turn
You'll be able to turn without stopping

correct.text: When turning right at a crossroads where oncoming traffic is also turning right, it's generally safer to turn behind the approaching vehicle. This allows you a clear view of approaching traffic and is called 'turning offside to offside'. However, some junctions, usually controlled by traffic-light filters - are marked for vehicles to turn nearside to nearside.

incorrect.text: When turning right at a crossroads where oncoming traffic is also turning right, it's generally safer to turn behind the approaching vehicle. This allows you a clear view of approaching traffic and is called 'turning offside to offside'. However, some junctions, usually controlled by traffic-light filters - are marked for vehicles to turn nearside to nearside.

config.text: You're driving on a busy main road. What should you do if you find that you're driving in the wrong direction?

choices.label: Turn into a side road on the right and reverse into the main road
Make a U-turn in the main road
Make a ‘three-point’ turn in the main road
Turn around in a side road

correct.text: Don’t turn around in a busy street or reverse from a side road into a main road. Find a quiet side road and choose a place to turn around where you won’t obstruct an entrance or exit. Look out for pedestrians and cyclists as well as other traffic.

incorrect.text: Don’t turn around in a busy street or reverse from a side road into a main road. Find a quiet side road and choose a place to turn around where you won’t obstruct an entrance or exit. Look out for pedestrians and cyclists as well as other traffic.

config.text: What should you do if you want to overtake a tractor but aren't sure that it's safe?

choices.label: Follow another vehicle as it overtakes the tractor
Sound your horn to make the tractor driver pull over
Speed past, flashing your lights at oncoming traffic
Stay behind it if you're in any doubt

correct.text: Following a tractor can be frustrating, but never overtake if you’re unsure whether it’s safe. Ask yourself: 'Can I see far enough down the road to ensure that I can complete the manoeuvre safely?' It's better to be delayed for a minute or two than to take a chance that may cause a collision.

incorrect.text: Following a tractor can be frustrating, but never overtake if you’re unsure whether it’s safe. Ask yourself: 'Can I see far enough down the road to ensure that I can complete the manoeuvre safely?' It's better to be delayed for a minute or two than to take a chance that may cause a collision.

config.text: What signal should you give when you're going straight ahead at a roundabout?

choices.label: Signal left before leaving the roundabout
Don't signal at any time
Signal right when you're approaching the roundabout
Signal left when you're approaching the roundabout

correct.text: When going straight ahead at a roundabout, don’t signal as you approach it. Signal left just after passing the exit before the one you wish to take.

incorrect.text: When going straight ahead at a roundabout, don’t signal as you approach it. Signal left just after passing the exit before the one you wish to take.

config.text: Other than direction indicators, how can you give signals to other road users?

choices.label: By using brake lights
By using sidelights
By using fog lights
By using interior lights

correct.text: Your brake lights will give an indication to traffic behind that you're slowing down. Good anticipation will allow you time to check your mirrors before slowing.

incorrect.text: Your brake lights will give an indication to traffic behind that you're slowing down. Good anticipation will allow you time to check your mirrors before slowing.

config.text: You want to park and you see this sign. What should you do on the days and times shown?

choices.label: Park in a bay and not pay
Park on yellow lines and pay
Park on yellow lines and not pay
Park in a bay and pay

correct.text: Parking restrictions apply in a variety of places and situations. Make sure you know the rules and understand where and when restrictions apply. Controlled parking areas will be indicated by signs and road markings. Parking in the wrong place could cause an obstruction and danger to other traffic. It can also result in a fine.

incorrect.text: Parking restrictions apply in a variety of places and situations. Make sure you know the rules and understand where and when restrictions apply. Controlled parking areas will be indicated by signs and road markings. Parking in the wrong place could cause an obstruction and danger to other traffic. It can also result in a fine.

config.text: Why could it be dangerous to reverse from a side road into a main road?

choices.label: Your reverse sensors will beep
Your view will be restricted
Your reversing lights will be hidden
Your mirrors will need adjusting

correct.text: Don’t reverse into a main road from a side road because your view will be restricted. The main road is likely to be busy and the traffic on it moving quickly.

incorrect.text: Don’t reverse into a main road from a side road because your view will be restricted. The main road is likely to be busy and the traffic on it moving quickly.

config.text: When must you stop your vehicle?

choices.label: If you’re involved in an incident that causes damage or injury
At a junction where there are ‘give way’ lines
At the end of a one-way street
Before merging onto a motorway

correct.text:
You must stop your vehicle when signalled to do so by a
  • police, DVSA or traffic officer
  • traffic warden
  • school crossing patrol
  • red traffic light.
You must also stop if you're involved in an incident that causes damage or injury to any other person, vehicle, animal or property.

incorrect.text:
You must stop your vehicle when signalled to do so by a
  • police, DVSA or traffic officer
  • traffic warden
  • school crossing patrol
  • red traffic light.
You must also stop if you're involved in an incident that causes damage or injury to any other person, vehicle, animal or property.

config.text: Where will you see these red and white markers?

choices.label: Approaching the end of a motorway
Approaching a concealed level crossing
Approaching a concealed speed-limit sign
Approaching the end of a dual carriageway

correct.text: If there's a bend just before a level crossing, you may not be able to see the level-crossing barriers or waiting traffic. These signs give you an early warning that you may find these hazards just around the bend.

incorrect.text: If there's a bend just before a level crossing, you may not be able to see the level-crossing barriers or waiting traffic. These signs give you an early warning that you may find these hazards just around the bend.

config.text: You're parked in a busy high street. What's the safest way to turn your vehicle around so you can drive in the opposite direction?

choices.label: Turn around in a quiet side road
Drive into a side road and reverse out into the main road
Ask someone to stop the traffic
Carry out a U-turn

correct.text: Make sure you carry out the manoeuvre without causing a hazard to other vehicles. Choose a place to turn that's safe and considers other road users.

incorrect.text: Make sure you carry out the manoeuvre without causing a hazard to other vehicles. Choose a place to turn that's safe and considers other road users.

config.text: What does this sign mean?

choices.label: No through road
End of traffic-calming zone
Free-parking zone ends
End of controlled parking zone

correct.text: This sign shows that you're leaving a controlled parking zone and those restrictions no longer apply.

incorrect.text: This sign shows that you're leaving a controlled parking zone and those restrictions no longer apply.

config.text: You're in a built-up area at night and the road is well lit. Why should you use dipped headlights?

choices.label: So that you can see further along the road
So that you can go at a much faster speed
So that you can switch to main beam quickly
So that you can be easily seen by others

correct.text: You may be difficult to see when you’re travelling at night, even on a well-lit road. If you use dipped headlights rather than sidelights, other road users should be able to see you more easily.

incorrect.text: You may be difficult to see when you’re travelling at night, even on a well-lit road. If you use dipped headlights rather than sidelights, other road users should be able to see you more easily.

config.text: You're reversing into a side road. When would your vehicle be the greatest hazard to passing traffic?

choices.label: After you’ve completed the manoeuvre
Just before you begin to manoeuvre
After you’ve entered the side road
When the front of your vehicle swings out

correct.text: Always check in all directions before reversing. Keep a good lookout throughout the manoeuvre and remember that the front will swing out as you reverse into the side road. Act on what you see and wait if necessary.

incorrect.text: Always check in all directions before reversing. Keep a good lookout throughout the manoeuvre and remember that the front will swing out as you reverse into the side road. Act on what you see and wait if necessary.

config.text: You're travelling along a residential street. There are parked vehicles on the left-hand side. Why should you keep your speed down?

choices.label: So that oncoming traffic can see you more clearly
You may set off car alarms
There may be delivery lorries on the street
Children may run out from between the vehicles

correct.text:
Travel slowly and carefully near parked vehicles. Beware of
  • vehicles pulling out, especially bicycles and motorcycles
  • pedestrians, especially children, who may run out from between cars
  • drivers opening their doors.

incorrect.text:
Travel slowly and carefully near parked vehicles. Beware of
  • vehicles pulling out, especially bicycles and motorcycles
  • pedestrians, especially children, who may run out from between cars
  • drivers opening their doors.

config.text: A cycle lane, marked by a solid white line, is in operation. What does this mean for car drivers?

choices.label: They may park in the lane
They may drive in the lane at any time
They may use the lane when necessary
They mustn't drive along the lane

correct.text: While it's in operation, other vehicles must not use this part of the carriageway except to pick up or set down passengers. At other times, when the lane isn't in operation, you should still be aware that there may be cyclists using the lane. Give them plenty of room as you pass and allow for their movement from side to side, especially in windy weather or on a bumpy road.

incorrect.text: While it's in operation, other vehicles must not use this part of the carriageway except to pick up or set down passengers. At other times, when the lane isn't in operation, you should still be aware that there may be cyclists using the lane. Give them plenty of room as you pass and allow for their movement from side to side, especially in windy weather or on a bumpy road.

config.text: What must you do if you come across roadworks that have a temporary speed limit displayed?

choices.label: Obey the speed limit
Obey the limit, but only during rush hour
Ignore the displayed limit
Use your own judgement; the limit is only advisory

correct.text: Where there are extra hazards, such as at roadworks, it's often necessary to slow traffic by imposing a lower speed limit. These speed limits aren't advisory; they must be obeyed.

incorrect.text: Where there are extra hazards, such as at roadworks, it's often necessary to slow traffic by imposing a lower speed limit. These speed limits aren't advisory; they must be obeyed.

config.text: Which road users benefit from toucan crossings?

choices.label: Car drivers and motorcyclists
Cyclists and pedestrians
Bus and lorry drivers
Tram and train drivers

correct.text: Toucan crossings are similar to pelican crossings but there's no flashing amber phase. Cyclists share the crossing with pedestrians and are allowed to cycle across when the green cycle symbol is shown.

incorrect.text: Toucan crossings are similar to pelican crossings but there's no flashing amber phase. Cyclists share the crossing with pedestrians and are allowed to cycle across when the green cycle symbol is shown.

config.text: You see these double white lines along the centre of the road. When may you park on the left?

choices.label: If the line nearest to you is broken
When there are no yellow lines
To pick up or set down passengers
During daylight hours only

correct.text: You mustn't park or stop on a road marked with double white lines (even where one of the lines is broken) except to pick up or set down passengers.

incorrect.text: You mustn't park or stop on a road marked with double white lines (even where one of the lines is broken) except to pick up or set down passengers.

config.text: You're turning right onto a dual carriageway. What should you do if the central reservation is too narrow to contain your vehicle?

choices.label: Proceed to the central reservation and wait
Wait until the road is clear in both directions
Stop in the first lane so that other vehicles give way
Emerge slightly to show your intentions

correct.text: When the central reservation is narrow, it may not be able to contain your vehicle. In this case, you should treat a dual carriageway as one road. Wait until the road is clear in both directions before emerging to turn right. If you try to treat it as two separate roads and wait in the middle, your vehicle will stick out and cause an obstruction that may lead to a collision.

incorrect.text: When the central reservation is narrow, it may not be able to contain your vehicle. In this case, you should treat a dual carriageway as one road. Wait until the road is clear in both directions before emerging to turn right. If you try to treat it as two separate roads and wait in the middle, your vehicle will stick out and cause an obstruction that may lead to a collision.

config.text: How should you signal if you're going straight ahead at a roundabout?

choices.label: Signal right on the approach and then left to leave the roundabout
Signal left after you leave the roundabout and enter the new road
Signal right on the approach to the roundabout and keep the signal on
Signal left just after you pass the exit before the one you're going to take

correct.text: To go straight ahead at a roundabout, you should normally approach in the left-hand lane, but check the road markings. At some roundabouts, the left lane on approach is marked ‘left turn only’, so make sure you use the correct lane to go ahead. You won't normally need to signal as you approach, but signal before you leave the roundabout, as other road users need to know your intentions.

incorrect.text: To go straight ahead at a roundabout, you should normally approach in the left-hand lane, but check the road markings. At some roundabouts, the left lane on approach is marked ‘left turn only’, so make sure you use the correct lane to go ahead. You won't normally need to signal as you approach, but signal before you leave the roundabout, as other road users need to know your intentions.

config.text: When may you drive a car in this bus lane?

choices.label: Outside its hours of operation
To get to the front of a traffic queue
You may not use it at any time
To overtake slow-moving traffic

correct.text: Some bus lanes operate only during peak hours and other vehicles may use them outside these hours. Make sure you check the sign for the hours of operation before driving in a bus lane.

incorrect.text: Some bus lanes operate only during peak hours and other vehicles may use them outside these hours. Make sure you check the sign for the hours of operation before driving in a bus lane.

config.text: Where should you park your vehicle at night?

choices.label: Near a police station
In a quiet road
On a red route
In a well-lit area

correct.text: When you're parking at night, park in a well-lit area. This can help deter criminals from targeting your vehicle.

incorrect.text: When you're parking at night, park in a well-lit area. This can help deter criminals from targeting your vehicle.

config.text: When may you drive without wearing your seat belt?

choices.label: When you're carrying out a manoeuvre that includes reversing
When you're moving off on a hill
When you're testing your brakes
When you're driving slowly in queuing traffic

correct.text: You may remove your seat belt while you're carrying out a manoeuvre that includes reversing. However, you must remember to put it back on again before you resume driving.

incorrect.text: You may remove your seat belt while you're carrying out a manoeuvre that includes reversing. However, you must remember to put it back on again before you resume driving.

config.text: When are you allowed to park in a parking bay for disabled drivers?

choices.label: When you have a Blue Badge
When you have a wheelchair
When you have an advanced driver certificate
When you have an adapted vehicle

correct.text: Don’t park in a space reserved for disabled people unless you or your passenger are a Blue Badge holder. The badge must be displayed on the dashboard or fascia panel, where it can be clearly read through the front windscreen.

incorrect.text: Don’t park in a space reserved for disabled people unless you or your passenger are a Blue Badge holder. The badge must be displayed on the dashboard or fascia panel, where it can be clearly read through the front windscreen.

config.text: You're looking for somewhere to park your vehicle. Neither you or your passenger are disabled. What should you do if the only free spaces are marked for disabled drivers?

choices.label: Use one of these spaces
Park in one of these spaces but stay with your vehicle
Use one of the spaces as long as one is kept free
Wait for a regular parking space to become free

correct.text: It's illegal to park in a space reserved for disabled drivers unless you're permitted to do so. These spaces are provided for people with limited mobility, who may need extra space to get in and out of their vehicle.

incorrect.text: It's illegal to park in a space reserved for disabled drivers unless you're permitted to do so. These spaces are provided for people with limited mobility, who may need extra space to get in and out of their vehicle.

config.text: What's the national speed limit on a single carriageway road for cars and motorcycles?

choices.label: 30 mph
50 mph
60 mph
70 mph

correct.text: Exceeding the speed limit is dangerous and can result in you receiving penalty points on your licence. It isn't worth it. You should know the speed limit for the road that you're on by observing the road signs. Different speed limits apply if you're towing a trailer.

incorrect.text: Exceeding the speed limit is dangerous and can result in you receiving penalty points on your licence. It isn't worth it. You should know the speed limit for the road that you're on by observing the road signs. Different speed limits apply if you're towing a trailer.

config.text: In England, Scotland and Northern Ireland what will the speed limit usually be where you can see street lights but no speed-limit signs?

choices.label: 30 mph
40 mph
50 mph
60 mph

correct.text:
In England, Scotland and Northern Ireland the presence of street lights generally indicates that there's a 30 mph speed limit, unless signs tell you otherwise.
In Wales street lights indicate the limit is 20 mph unless signs show otherwise.

incorrect.text:
In England, Scotland and Northern Ireland the presence of street lights generally indicates that there's a 30 mph speed limit, unless signs tell you otherwise.
In Wales street lights indicate the limit is 20 mph unless signs show otherwise.

config.text: What's the speed limit for a car towing a caravan on a dual carriageway?

choices.label: 50 mph
40 mph
70 mph
60 mph

correct.text: The speed limit for cars towing caravans or trailers on dual carriageways or motorways is 60 mph. Due to the increased weight and size of the combination, you should plan further ahead. Take care in windy weather, as a strong side wind can make a caravan or large trailer unstable.

incorrect.text: The speed limit for cars towing caravans or trailers on dual carriageways or motorways is 60 mph. Due to the increased weight and size of the combination, you should plan further ahead. Take care in windy weather, as a strong side wind can make a caravan or large trailer unstable.

config.text: When may you drive over a pavement?

choices.label: To overtake slow-moving traffic
When the pavement is very wide
If there are no pedestrians nearby
To gain access to a property

correct.text: It's illegal to drive on or over a pavement, except to gain access to a property. If you need to cross a pavement, give priority to pedestrians.

incorrect.text: It's illegal to drive on or over a pavement, except to gain access to a property. If you need to cross a pavement, give priority to pedestrians.

config.text: When may you stop on a clearway?

choices.label: Never
When it's busy
In the rush hour
During daylight hours

correct.text: Clearways are in place so that traffic can flow without the obstruction of parked vehicles. Just one parked vehicle can cause an obstruction for all other traffic. You mustn't stop where a clearway is in force, not even to pick up or set down passengers.

incorrect.text: Clearways are in place so that traffic can flow without the obstruction of parked vehicles. Just one parked vehicle can cause an obstruction for all other traffic. You mustn't stop where a clearway is in force, not even to pick up or set down passengers.

config.text: When may you stop and wait in a box junction?

choices.label: When oncoming traffic prevents you from turning right
When you're in a queue of traffic turning left
When you're in a queue of traffic going ahead
When you're on a roundabout

correct.text: The purpose of yellow box markings is to keep junctions clear of queuing traffic. You may only wait in the marked area when you’re turning right and your exit lane is clear but you can’t complete the turn because of oncoming traffic or other traffic waiting to turn right.

incorrect.text: The purpose of yellow box markings is to keep junctions clear of queuing traffic. You may only wait in the marked area when you’re turning right and your exit lane is clear but you can’t complete the turn because of oncoming traffic or other traffic waiting to turn right.

config.text: You're looking for somewhere to park at night. When may you park on the right-hand side of the road?

choices.label: When you're in a one-way street
When you have your sidelights on
When you're more than 10 metres (32 feet) from a junction
When you're under a lamppost

correct.text: Red rear reflectors show up when headlights shine on them. These are useful when you're parked at night, but they'll only reflect if you park in the same direction as the traffic flow. Normally you should park on the left, but in a one-way street you may also park on the right-hand side of the road.

incorrect.text: Red rear reflectors show up when headlights shine on them. These are useful when you're parked at night, but they'll only reflect if you park in the same direction as the traffic flow. Normally you should park on the left, but in a one-way street you may also park on the right-hand side of the road.

config.text: You’re waiting at a pelican crossing. What does it mean when the red light changes to flashing amber?

choices.label: Give way to pedestrians on the crossing
Move off immediately without any hesitation
Wait for the green light before moving off
Get ready and go when the continuous amber light shows

correct.text: This light allows pedestrians already on the crossing to get to the other side in their own time, without being rushed. Don’t rev your engine or start to move off while they’re still crossing.

incorrect.text: This light allows pedestrians already on the crossing to get to the other side in their own time, without being rushed. Don’t rev your engine or start to move off while they’re still crossing.

config.text: When would you use the right-hand lane of a two-lane dual carriageway?

choices.label: When you're turning right or overtaking
When you're passing a side road on the left
When you're staying at the minimum allowed speed
When you're travelling at a constant high speed

correct.text: Normally you should travel in the left-hand lane and only use the right-hand lane for overtaking or turning right. Move back into the left lane as soon as it’s safe but don’t cut in across the path of the vehicle you’ve just passed.

incorrect.text: Normally you should travel in the left-hand lane and only use the right-hand lane for overtaking or turning right. Move back into the left lane as soon as it’s safe but don’t cut in across the path of the vehicle you’ve just passed.

config.text: What should you do if the amber lights come on and a warning sounds while you're driving over a level crossing?

choices.label: Get everyone out of the vehicle immediately
Stop and reverse back to clear the crossing
Keep going and clear the crossing
Stop immediately and use your hazard warning lights

correct.text: Keep going; don’t stop on the crossing. If the warning sounds and the amber lights come on as you’re approaching the crossing, you must stop unless it's unsafe to do so. Red flashing lights together with the audible warning mean you must stop.

incorrect.text: Keep going; don’t stop on the crossing. If the warning sounds and the amber lights come on as you’re approaching the crossing, you must stop unless it's unsafe to do so. Red flashing lights together with the audible warning mean you must stop.

meta.xref: DES s6, HC r293, KYTS p30

config.text: You're waiting at a level crossing. What should you do if the red warning lights continue to flash after a train has passed by?

choices.label: Get out and investigate
Telephone the signal operator
Continue to wait
Drive across carefully

correct.text: At a level crossing, flashing red lights mean you must stop. If the train passes but the lights keep flashing, wait. Another train may be coming.

incorrect.text: At a level crossing, flashing red lights mean you must stop. If the train passes but the lights keep flashing, wait. Another train may be coming.

config.text: Which vehicle is most likely to take an unusual course at a roundabout?

choices.label: Estate car
Taxi
Delivery van
Long vehicle

correct.text: Long vehicles might have to take a slightly different position when approaching the roundabout or going around it. This is to stop the rear of the vehicle cutting in and mounting the kerb.

incorrect.text: Long vehicles might have to take a slightly different position when approaching the roundabout or going around it. This is to stop the rear of the vehicle cutting in and mounting the kerb.

config.text: What's the meaning of this sign?

choices.label: No entry
Waiting restrictions
National speed limit
School crossing patrol

correct.text:
This sign indicates that there are waiting restrictions. It's normally accompanied by details of when the restrictions are in force.
Details of most signs in common use are shown in The Highway Code. For more comprehensive coverage, see Know Your Traffic Signs.

incorrect.text:
This sign indicates that there are waiting restrictions. It's normally accompanied by details of when the restrictions are in force.
Details of most signs in common use are shown in The Highway Code. For more comprehensive coverage, see Know Your Traffic Signs.

config.text: When should you use the right-hand lane of a three-lane dual carriageway?

choices.label: When you're overtaking only
When you're overtaking or turning right
When you're using cruise control
When you're turning right only

correct.text:
You should normally use the left-hand lane on any dual carriageway unless you're overtaking or turning right.
When overtaking on a dual carriageway, look for vehicles ahead that are turning right. They may be slowing or stopped. You need to see them in good time so that you can take appropriate action.

incorrect.text:
You should normally use the left-hand lane on any dual carriageway unless you're overtaking or turning right.
When overtaking on a dual carriageway, look for vehicles ahead that are turning right. They may be slowing or stopped. You need to see them in good time so that you can take appropriate action.

meta.xref: DES s6, HC r293, KYTS p30

config.text: You're waiting at a level crossing. What must you do if a train passes but the lights keep flashing?

choices.label: Carry on waiting
Phone the signal operator
Edge over the stop line and look for trains
Park and investigate

correct.text: If the lights at a level crossing keep flashing after a train has passed, you should continue to wait, because another train might be coming. Time seems to pass slowly when you're held up in a queue. Be patient and wait until the lights stop flashing.

incorrect.text: If the lights at a level crossing keep flashing after a train has passed, you should continue to wait, because another train might be coming. Time seems to pass slowly when you're held up in a queue. Be patient and wait until the lights stop flashing.

config.text: You're approaching a busy junction. What should you do when, at the last moment, you realise you're in the wrong lane?

choices.label: Continue in that lane
Force your way into the lane you need
Stop until the area has cleared
Use arm signals to help you change lane

correct.text: There are times when road markings are obscured by queuing traffic, or you're unsure which lane to use. If, at the last moment, you find you're in the wrong lane, don’t cut across or bully other drivers to let you in. Follow the lane you’re in and find somewhere safe to turn around and rejoin your route.

incorrect.text: There are times when road markings are obscured by queuing traffic, or you're unsure which lane to use. If, at the last moment, you find you're in the wrong lane, don’t cut across or bully other drivers to let you in. Follow the lane you’re in and find somewhere safe to turn around and rejoin your route.

config.text: What should you do when you're unsure whether it's safe to reverse your vehicle?

choices.label: Sound your horn
Rev your engine
Get out and check
Reverse slowly

correct.text: A small child could be hidden directly behind you, so, if you can't see all around your vehicle, get out and have a look. You could also ask someone reliable outside the vehicle to guide you.

incorrect.text: A small child could be hidden directly behind you, so, if you can't see all around your vehicle, get out and have a look. You could also ask someone reliable outside the vehicle to guide you.

config.text: What should you do when you park at night on a road that has a 40 mph speed limit?

choices.label: Park facing the traffic
Leave parking lights switched on
Leave dipped headlights switched on
Park near a street light

correct.text: You must use parking lights when parking at night on a road or in a lay-by on a road with a speed limit greater than 30 mph. You must also park in the direction of the traffic flow and not close to a junction.

incorrect.text: You must use parking lights when parking at night on a road or in a lay-by on a road with a speed limit greater than 30 mph. You must also park in the direction of the traffic flow and not close to a junction.

config.text: Who has priority at an unmarked crossroads?

choices.label: The larger vehicle
No-one has priority
The faster vehicle
The smaller vehicle

correct.text: Practise good observation in all directions before you emerge or make a turn. Proceed only when you're sure it's safe to do so.

incorrect.text: Practise good observation in all directions before you emerge or make a turn. Proceed only when you're sure it's safe to do so.

config.text: How far are you allowed to reverse?

choices.label: No further than is necessary
No more than a car’s length
As far as it takes to reverse around a corner
The length of a residential street

correct.text: You mustn't reverse further than is necessary. You may decide to turn your vehicle around by reversing into an opening or side road. When you reverse, always look all around you and watch for pedestrians. Don’t reverse from a side road into a main road.

incorrect.text: You mustn't reverse further than is necessary. You may decide to turn your vehicle around by reversing into an opening or side road. When you reverse, always look all around you and watch for pedestrians. Don’t reverse from a side road into a main road.

config.text: What's the national speed limit for cars and motorcycles on a dual carriageway?

choices.label: 30 mph
50 mph
60 mph
70 mph

correct.text: Make sure that you know the speed limit for the road that you're on. The speed limit on a dual carriageway or motorway is 70 mph for cars and motorcycles, unless signs indicate otherwise. The speed limits for different types of vehicle are listed in The Highway Code.

incorrect.text: Make sure that you know the speed limit for the road that you're on. The speed limit on a dual carriageway or motorway is 70 mph for cars and motorcycles, unless signs indicate otherwise. The speed limits for different types of vehicle are listed in The Highway Code.

config.text: You're driving at night with your headlights on main beam. A vehicle is overtaking you. When should you dip your headlights?

choices.label: Some time after the vehicle has passed you
Before the vehicle starts to pass you
Only if the other driver dips their headlights
As soon as the vehicle passes you

correct.text: On main beam, your lights could dazzle the driver in front. Dip your headlights as soon as the driver passes you and drop back so that the dipped beam falls short of the vehicle in front.

incorrect.text: On main beam, your lights could dazzle the driver in front. Dip your headlights as soon as the driver passes you and drop back so that the dipped beam falls short of the vehicle in front.

config.text: What should you do if you see a pedestrian waiting at a zebra crossing?

choices.label: Go on quickly before they step onto the crossing
Stop before you reach the zigzag lines and let them cross
Be ready to slow down or stop to let them cross
Ignore them as they're still on the pavement

correct.text: By standing on the pavement, the pedestrian is showing an intention to cross. By looking well ahead, you'll give yourself time to see the pedestrian, check your mirrors and respond safely.

incorrect.text: By standing on the pavement, the pedestrian is showing an intention to cross. By looking well ahead, you'll give yourself time to see the pedestrian, check your mirrors and respond safely.

config.text: There are no speed-limit signs on the road. In England, Scotland and Northern Ireland how is a 30 mph limit generally indicated?

choices.label: By hazard warning lines
By street lighting
By pedestrian islands
By double or single yellow lines

correct.text:
In England, Scotland and Northern Ireland, there's a 30 mph speed limit where there are street lights unless signs show another limit.
In Wales street lights indicate the limit is 20 mph unless signs show otherwise.

incorrect.text:
In England, Scotland and Northern Ireland, there's a 30 mph speed limit where there are street lights unless signs show another limit.
In Wales street lights indicate the limit is 20 mph unless signs show otherwise.

config.text: You're on a road that's only wide enough for one vehicle. What should you do if a car is coming towards you?

choices.label: Pull into a passing place on your right
Force the other driver to reverse
Pull into a passing place if your vehicle is wider
Pull into a passing place on your left

correct.text: Pull into the nearest passing place on the left if you meet another vehicle on a narrow road. If the nearest passing place is on the right, wait opposite it.

incorrect.text: Pull into the nearest passing place on the left if you meet another vehicle on a narrow road. If the nearest passing place is on the right, wait opposite it.

config.text: Where may you overtake on a one-way street?

choices.label: Only on the left-hand side
Overtaking isn't allowed
Only on the right-hand side
On either the right or the left

correct.text: You can overtake other traffic on either side when travelling in a one-way street. Make full use of your mirrors and ensure it's clear all around before you attempt to overtake. Look for signs and road markings, and use the most suitable lane for your destination.

incorrect.text: You can overtake other traffic on either side when travelling in a one-way street. Make full use of your mirrors and ensure it's clear all around before you attempt to overtake. Look for signs and road markings, and use the most suitable lane for your destination.

config.text: You're travelling on a motorway in England. When must you stop your vehicle?

choices.label: When signalled to stop by a roadworks supervisor
When signalled to stop by a traffic officer
When signalled to stop by a pedestrian on the hard shoulder
When signalled to stop by a driver who has broken down

correct.text: You'll find traffic officers on motorways and some primary routes in England and Wales. They work in partnership with the police, helping to keep traffic moving and helping to make your journey as safe as possible. It's an offence not to comply with the directions given by a traffic officer.

incorrect.text: You'll find traffic officers on motorways and some primary routes in England and Wales. They work in partnership with the police, helping to keep traffic moving and helping to make your journey as safe as possible. It's an offence not to comply with the directions given by a traffic officer.
